title: William George (priest)
text:
William George (died 1756) was an English churchman and academic, Provost of <a href="King%27s%20College%2C%20Cambridge">King's College, Cambridge</a> from 1743 and <a href="Dean%20of%20Lincoln">Dean of Lincoln</a> from 1748.
Life.
Born in London, he was educated at <a href="Eton%20College">Eton College</a> and admitted to King's College, Cambridge, in 1715. He proceeded to his degree of B.A. 1719, M.A. 1723, and D.D. 1728. Leaving university, he became assistant-master, and eventually principal, of Eton, a position he held for around 15 years. George, a fine scholar, had little of the necessary touch with the boys, who in 1729 rioted spectacularly in a pupil rebellion, unique in Eton's history.
In 1731 George was a canon of Windsor and chaplain <a href="in%20ordinary">in ordinary</a> to George II. His further advancement was a result of the backing of <a href="Sir%20Robert%20Walpole">Sir Robert Walpole</a>, the Prime Minister. George left his scholastic career in 1743, when he was appointed to the vacant provostship of King's College, Cambridge: his race was a genuine contest with <a href="John%20Chapman%20%28theologian%29">John Chapman</a>, also a candidate, but George succeeded by 28 votes to 10. The same year he was also elected vice-chancellor of Cambridge.
In 1747, the <a href="deanery%20of%20Winchester">deanery of Winchester</a> fell vacant, and George was nominated; but for the sake of his friend <a href="Samuel%20Pegge">Samuel Pegge</a>, he exchanged it for the deanery of Lincoln, where he was installed in 1748. He also resigned in favour of Dr. Pegge his rectory of <a href="Old%20Whittington">Whittington, Derbyshire</a>. He died on 2 August 1756.
Works.
George was a popular preacher, and several of his sermons were printed, among them a sermon preached before the <a href="Society%20for%20the%20Propagation%20of%20the%20Gospel">Society for the Propagation of the Gospel</a>, 1732, and a second delivered before the House of Commons in 1752. He was also a Greek scholar and Latin poet: some of his poems were in the "Musæ Etonenses" (1755), edited by John Prinsep. Some lines on the death of <a href="Frederick%2C%20Prince%20of%20Wales">Frederick, Prince of Wales</a> were the topic of an anecdote of <a href="Pope%20Benedict%20XIV">Pope Benedict XIV</a>.
Family.
During his residence at Eton, George married Miss Bland, daughter of <a href="Henry%20Bland">Henry Bland</a>, his predecessor.
